title: Riot, it's time to stop supporting 32 bit systems!
body:
It took Riot untill **APRIL 2019** to stop supporting Windows XP and Vista (Who the hell even uses that tractor of an OS?), and [in a very recent Nexus post ](https://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/en-gb/2019/12/unleashing-the-elements/)it was confirmed that League could not be too graphically intense, because it is still made to be supported by 32 bit machines.

But that's also one of the reasons why the game's client is in such a horrible state, and why Riot refuses to re-build and re-code it from the ground up. Because, sadly, League is still being taylored to be internet cafe friendly. In it's core, League is still a small 2009 game, stuck together with toothpicks and duct tape. And it should not be this way! The constant complaints about stablility speak for themselves.
Stopping support for outdated OSes was the first step towards modernization. Now is the time for the second!

_"But...but... How will i play LoL Of Legends from my 32 bit laptoop?"_
Upgrade your hardware? 
I don't want to see League staying outdated when it comes to coding and build. Rarely anybody uses 32 bit anymore. and the percent is only going to go down. Just like with Windows XP and Vista users.

For a compay that is supposed to be one of the "market leaders", Riot is definitely staying behind.

Even electronics have wear and tear, and a refurbished ancient machine won't last as long as a new one, in terms of how long you can reasonably use it before needing to upgrade again and how long you can use it before it starts getting physical failures. And I highly doubt you'll find many people who would appreciate being told "you can get such-and-such computer for $100" when it's a refurb of an ancient model for $150.

not only this but the key difference between 32 and 64 bit processing is simply how much ram/data storage an OS on each can handle. league in itself only requires about 2 to run. a 32 bit machine handles up to 4. 

there would quite literally be no reason to not have it be playable on a 32 bit machine. using a 32 bit program on a 64 bit machine runs it at a 32 bit level but if it needs more ram, it can readily request it. being that the client at its peak will use about 600, whether it runs on a 32 or 64 bit machine would be functionally the same.

Do you know why Microsoft has so many more bugs on updates now?

Its because they basically got rid of their PC bugtesting in favor of homogenizing the OS between Xbox, windows, and windows phone.

They used to have a HUGE array of PC hardware configurations to bugtest updates on, which led to us very rarely having major issues with new updates. Since they got rid of that, it seems like every update has major issues.

Lower hardware variety leads to greater stability because it minimizes inconsistencies.
